prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Initiating Panel proceedings—Methods of initiating proceedings

para.paratext: Proceedings before the Panel can be initiated either by the Panel or by motion of a litigant.[1] Proceedings before the Panel are essentially the same regardless of whether the Panel or a litigant initiates transfer. However, the Panel has infrequently exercised its power to initiate transfer proceedings where there have been no related cases before it, so the focus of this section is on initiation of transfer proceedings by a party.[2] (In contrast, the Panel often initiates transfer of a single case related to other cases previously transferred by the Panel. Such cases, called “tag-along” actions, are discussed in chapter 8.)

The Panel does encourage clerks of district courts to advise the Panel of actions that may be suitable for consideration of transfer by the Panel.[3] The Panel relies on notices of related cases filed in the individual district courts to identify actions that may be appropriate for consideration by the Panel.[4] The filing of a notice of related case is encouraged by the Manual for Complex Litigation[5] and is required by some local district court rules. A notice of related case may be used to permit the transfer of related cases to a single judge within a district as well as identify cases that may be appropriate for treatment by the Panel.[6]

The Panel also uses computer records derived from the filing of civil cover sheets describing the type of action filed in every United States district court to identify potential multidistrict cases.[7] The clerks of the various district courts may also monitor filings in their districts to identify multidistrict cases.[8] Some districts specifically require identification of cases that may be suitable for consideration by the Panel.[9]

By rule, initiation of transfer by the Panel when it becomes aware of new cases is by show cause order.[10] When the Panel becomes aware of potential tag-along actions, it uses a conditional transfer order to advise the parties that transfer will be considered.[11] Many Panel proceedings have been initiated by the Panel. The Panel has frequently ordered transfer in these cases,[12] although it has also denied transfer.[13] Even where the Panel initiates proceedings sua sponte, it may decline to order transfer.[14] It is likely to order transfer, however, if the parties do not respond to the conditional transfer order or order to show cause.[15]

The Panel frequently initiates transfer of “tag-along” actions, actions related to cases previously transferred by the Panel to a single district for coordinated or consolidated pre-trial proceedings.[16] In addition to initiating transfer proceedings for tag-along actions, the Panel is also quite likely to order transfer of them.[17]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

Transfer has been initiated by the Panel in a few cases. See, e.g., In re Helicopter Crash Near Cameron, La., 443 F. Supp. 1022 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Hamilton Bank (of Atlanta) Securities Litigation, 438 F. Supp. 940 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Oral Contraceptives Products, 322 F. Supp. 1011 (J.P.M.L. 1971); In re Admission Tickets, 302 F. Supp. 1339 (J.P.M.L. 1969); In re Grain Shipments, 300 F. Supp. 1402 (J.P.M.L. 1969); In re Protection Devices and Equipment and Central Station Protection Service Antitrust Cases, 295 F. Supp. 39 (J.P.M.L. 1968). The Panel was especially likely to initiate transfer of actions pending in the federal courts at the time 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 went into effect; as the availability and efficacy of transfer has become better known, it is more likely to be sought by motion of a party.
See Patricia Howard, A Guide to Multidistrict Litigation, 75 F.R.D. 577, 580 to 581 (1978). Mrs. Howard served as the Clerk of the Panel at its creation.

Failure to make a timely response to a motion for transfer is deemed acquiescence in the motion. J.P.M.L. R. 6.1(c). The Panel rules are reproduced in § 4:34. The Panel's application of this rule is discussed in § 4:16.

Chapter 8 is devoted to discussion of the similarities and differences of tag-along actions. The Panel Rules specifically provide for initiation of transfer of tag-along actions sua sponte. J.P.M.L. R. 7.1(a). The Panel rules are reproduced in § 4:34.
